thread.title: As the second season of historical epic Kynren approaches, what can visitors expect?

author: David Whetstone
title: As the second season of historical epic Kynren approaches, what can visitors expect?
text:
What's On As the second season of historical epic Kynren approaches, what can visitors expect? Kynren - An Epic Tale of England attracted 100,000 people to its Bishop Auckland arena in 2016. Here's how they aim to beat that Share   
The second season of Kynren – An Epic Tale of England starts on Saturday (July 1) but there was a dress rehearsal and media preview at the weekend. 
This provided the first opportunity to see how the show, purporting to tell 2,000 years of English history with a North East slant, has developed since its debut season in 2016. 
Hundreds gathered for the occasion at the purpose-built arena below Auckland Castle in Bishop Auckland . From next weekend, when the first of this season’s 17 performances takes place, it will be thousands. 
The uncovered grandstand, known as the Tribune, seats 8,000 people and the organisers, who work for the charity Eleven Arches (the name taken from Bishop Auckland’s famous viaduct), are confident of topping last year’s total audience of 100,000. 
If you saw Kynren in 2016 you will enjoy spotting changes and innovations. 
So what’s new for 2017? THE SOUNDTRACK 
Recruited to do the narration this time was popular actor Kevin Whately whose familiar voice over the PA system accentuates the North East flavour of the show, described as “the story of us”. 
Welcoming the audience, he suggests that the Kynren animals love the applause just as much as the human participants. 
Other new contributors for 2017 are the Spennymoor and Ferryhill Colliery bands which recorded new music for the show in Durham Cathedral – and will be present to entertain at the first public performance on Saturday. 
Nathan Stornetta’s score, worthy of a big-screen blockbuster, now has a touch of brass to add authenticity to its Durham Miners’ Gala scenes, although the musicians you see in the arena will be miming, just like all other Kynren performers. THE FEMALE PERSPECTIVE Queen Boudicca puts in a first appearance at Kynren (Photo: Peter Haygarth for Eleven Arches) 
In 2016 the action began with a lone boy, Arthur, kicking a football across the arena. This year he has two friends with him and one, on Saturday, was a girl. 
The need for more emphasis on the part played by women in our nation’s history was acknowledged last year. 
Putting in an early appearance is Boudicca (or Boedicea) mounted on one of Kynren’s splendid grey horses. Boudicca led a spirited uprising against the occupying Romans in Britain in 60 AD. 
Elizabeth I, or ‘Good Queen Bess’, gets a bit more time in the spotlight this year and the British Empire tableau with Queen Victoria is one of the most visually stunning. 
While most of the combat scenes involve men, lots of girls and women appear in the big showstopping scenes including the choreographed harvest festival symbolising agrarian Britain before the Industrial Revolution. THE ANIMALS 
They were stars in 2016 and the show would be the poorer without them. 
At the dress rehearsal Kynren’s horses were busy, whether pulling great carts or Queen Victoria’s carriage or galloping full pelt as mounted knights tilted at targets in the dramatic jousting scene. 
But, as last year, it was the farm animals which caused laughter and gasps of amazement. 
There are more geese this year to run in literally unflappable fashion across the arena and seemingly a bigger flock of sheep and lambs to do likewise. 
Adult cows – Durham shorthorns – appear for the first time and there are goats and a donkey. 
Seagulls from Lindisfarne also appear but they were clearly the work of human hands and are waved above the heads of some of Kynren’s many child performers. THE SPECIAL EFFECTS The grand finale - Kynren 2017 (Photo: Peter Haygarth for Eleven Arches) 
Ahead of this season Eleven Arches announced a new creative director, Steve Boyd, who has worked on umpteen Olympic and Paralympic ceremonies. 
Extra depth and detail were promised and have been delivered. 
There’s a beautiful depiction of Durham Cathedral using fountains and even the building’s famous rose window apppears within the falling spray. Very clever and effective. 
In the First World War sequence, which has been much improved and focuses on the temporary truce of Christmas 1914, snow – presumably fake, although it can get chilly here even in the summer – wafts across the arena. 
The early steam locomotive representing the pioneering Stockton to Darlington railway makes a welcome return. 
And the fireworks again make for a truly memorable grand finale which comes after victory in the Second World War (dealt with in sketchy fashion with a projection of Winston Churchill and recorded excerpts of some of his stirring speeches). 
Anyone hoping for an update – Brexit, perhaps – will be disappointed. THE MAIN MAN 
In the audience on Saturday was millionaire philanthropist Jonathan Ruffer whose plan to boost the fortunes of Bishop Auckland and County Durham include Kynren, Eleven Arches and the Auckland Castle Trust which is transforming the castle into a major visitor attraction as well as developing town centre art galleries. 
Asked for his impressions as the applause died down, he said: “It’s rather hard to think of the words really. But didn’t everyone just do brilliantly? 
“Having been to every performance except one last year, I’ve got to know every little detail. 
“This year has been sharpened up so much, the timing and everything. 
“With a bit of good fortune we’ll be up on the 100,000 tickets sold last year and if we sell the whole lot that’ll be more than 140,000.” 
Mr Ruffer praised the local volunteers who have taken Kynren to their hearts. 
“We have 1,500 community volunteers and the time will come when we have a waiting list.” 
Kynren: Time is running out to volunteer for this year's epic pageant - here's how to get involved VOLUNTEERS 
One thing which remains the same for 2017 is the cheerful determination of the local volunteers – the so-called ‘archers’ – to ensure everyone has a good time. 
Many of those volunteers not wearing costumes in the arena are part of the hospitality team with their pale trousers and red fleeces. 
There are so many that you wonder if anyone is left in Bishop Auckland on show nights. 
While some are back for a second year, there are also plenty of first-timers from across the North East. There was talk of a volunteer who is commuting from Kent. 
Among the many friendly archers on duty on Saturday was 63-year-old Heather Hopton, from the nearby village of Toronto. 
“Some of the people I work with were involved with the show last year so I came to see it and thought it was brilliant,” she said. 
“This year I thought I’d give it a go and I’ve been down two or three times for training. 
“The children in the show are really good and they really enjoy it. They make new friends and I think it brings them out if they’re a bit shy.” 
Kynren: Time is running out to volunteer for this year's epic pageant - here's how to get involved THE DETAILS 
There will be 17 performances of Kynren in 2017 with increasingly early start times as the nights draw in. 
Performances are on July 1, 7, 8, 14 and 15 (all 9.30pm); July 21 and 22, August 11 and 12 (9pm); August 18 and 19 (8.30pm); August 26 and 27, and September 1, 2, 9 and 16 (all 8pm). 
Tickets are on sale now at www.kynren.co.uk Like us on Facebook
